The crew had been' taken on board the German submarine responsible for the sinking, which had landed them at Dingle Bay. Two British mines had been driven ashore at Dover by rough seas, causing considerable explosions, but no casualties.

Salvage of 3. The Prime Minister asked what progress had been made
H.M.S. Thetis, with the salvage of the Thetis and whether anything had been discovered which might help Mr. Justice Bucknill's inquiry.
The First Lord of the Admiralty and The Chief of Naval Staff explained that it had not yet been possible to beach the Thetis. Work was being done on her from stern to bow and it was thought that the most important evidence regarding the cause of the accident would be found after examination of the torpedo compartment in the bow, which had not yet been reached. The effect of the acid on the interior of the Thetis Was such as to make it impossible to use the vessel as a warship.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
The Military Situation.

4. The Secretary of State for War said that the transfer of the Second Corps to France had now been completed. The troops which we had undertaken to send to France had now all been transported, and within the stipulated period, but there were certain additional units still to be transported. He took the opportunity to express the thanks of the War Office to the Admiralty for the protection which they had offered, and which had resulted in the passage of these Divisions being carried out without a single casualty, or a hitch of any kind. The Secretary of State for Air associated himself with this expression of thanks.
It was agreed that the First Lord of the Admiralty should send a private message of appreciation to the responsible Flotilla Leaders.
The Secretary of State for War read extracts from a personal letter from Lord Gort describing the general situation of our Army in France. Lord Gort was definitely of the opinion that the Germans, in their attack on the Western Front, would make full use of their Air Force against our troops. He therefore advocated that we should at once send the anti-aircraft batteries and fighters for which the French were asking, the more so as there was evidence that the French would expect us to increase our land effort.
A discussion ensued as to whether publicity should now be given to the activities of the Army. The Secretary of State for Air was to make a statement in the House the following Tuesday, and [20106] b 2
312
it was agreed that the Secretary of State for War should make a statement two days later. Meanwhile, arrangements had been made to advance the date of the departure of foreign Press correspondents, some 25 to 30 of whom would consequently be leaving for France on the following Monday.
The Chief of the Imperial General Staff informed the War Cabinet that the present dispositions of the German Army were 55 Divisions in the East, 17 Divisions in the centre, and 52 in the West, making a total of 124 Divisions in all. The evidence therefore was that, as yet, no considerable movement had been started from East to West.
It was generally agreed that this could be interpreted as implying lack of confidence in the Russians on Germany's part.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.

9. The War Cabinet had under consideration a Memorandum by the First Lord of the Admiralty (Paper W.P. (39) 57).
The President of the Board of Trade stated that, as he had already informed the Foreign Secretary, the Norwegian Delegation had late the previous night received instructions from their Government to return home to report.
The time had now arrived at which it was necessary to speak plainly to the Norwegian Government, and to let them know that if they took a difficult line over shipping, we should have no option but to take a difficult line over imports of coal to Norway from the United Kingdom. He hoped that the Foreign Secretary would see his way to speak in this sense to the Norwegian Minister.
The Foreign Secretary agreed to do so.
The War Cabinet took note that no action on our part would be necessary unless supplies from Narvik to Germany started moving once more. In that event the Royal Navy would take drastic action.

The greater part of the Dutch mercantile marine was, however, engaged in the trade with the Dutch East Indies. Proposal for the Paragraph 4 of the First Lord's Memorandum outlined a chartering and wider proposal, namely, that we should secure the control, by charter insurance of all or otherwise, of all the free neutral shipping we could obtain and available neutral thus secure to ourselves power to regulate the greater part of the tonnage. sea transport of the world and to recharter it, profitably, to those
who acted in accordance with our wishes; and further, that we might extend to neutral shipping not under our direct control the benefit of our convoy system.
It was believed at the Admiralty that this large undertaking would not be beyond our strength. Had some such scheme for the chartering and insurance of neutral shipping been in force from the early days of the last war, there could be little doubt that it would have proved a highly profitable speculation. In the present war it might prove to be the foundation of a League of Free Maritime Nations.
A preliminary discussion made it clear that the War Cabinet were attracted by this new proposal. They felt, however, that they would not be in a position to take decisions upon it until plans had been worked out by the Departments concerned in considerable detail. Among other matters the question would arise whether the Navy, at its existing strength, was in a position to undertake the additional convoy duties which "-would be involved.
The War Cabinet were informed that cases had already occurred in which neutral ships had requested permission to join our convoys. The Navy had put no obstacles in the way of their doing so.

The Russians had now come forward with a proposal that both

parties should buy their goods f.o.b, and that a rendezvous should be appointed at which the physical exchange of the goods would take place. The procedure would be that each side would send a convoy to the rendezvous, the names of the vessels composing the convoy having been previously notified to the other party. The vessels would arrive from British ports on the one hand and from Archangel on the other. Two places had been suggested for the rendezvous, namely, the port of Narvik and the limit of the Soviet territorial waters outside Murmansk.
The Soviet Authorities appeared to be willing to conclude a mutually advantageous bargain on the above lines. It was not proposed that the whole of the goods covered by the negotiations should be exchanged on one occasion. This would be impracticable as there were as many as 58 vessels (42 neutral and 16 British) either loading timber or taking refuge in North Russian ports.
The Minister explained that the Soviet Trade Commissioner was expecting to hear from him at 2 o'clock that afternoon.
The First Lord of the A dmiralty said that the Admiralty saw no objection to the proposed method of exchanging goods at a rendezvous. Our Naval escorts would be prepared to undertake convoy duty as far as the rendezvous. The Admiralty might, indeed, sometimes think it desirable to extend our patrols somewhat beyond the rendezvous, in the direction of the White Sea ports. As regards the place to be appointed as the rendezvous, the Admiralty would prefer Narvik, but were prepared, if necessary, to agree to the limit of territorial waters outside Murmansk.
The War Cabinet took note of the stage reached in the Anglo-Soviet trade negotiations; and authorised the Minister of Supply to proceed with the proposal outlined ,for an exchange of ships and cargoes at a rendezvous.

11. The First Lord of the Admiralty informed the War Cabinet of certain communications which he had had in regard to this matter. He read out a message which, on the advice of the Naval Staff, he proposed to communicate informally to the United States Government.
Fuller details in regard to this matter are recorded in the Secretary's Standard File of War Cabinet Conclusions.

Armistice Day. 12. The Home Secretary raised the question of the observance
this year of Armistice Day. He had been in touch with the Archbishop of Canterbury and all interested Departments. As a result, it had been agreed that no general celebration could take place in present circumstances. No obstacle would, however, be placed in the way of local observance of the day, if desired by small communities. It was proposed that the usual Poppy Day collection, under the auspices of the British Legion, should take place on the 11th November, and that Sunday, the 12th November, should be observed as a Day of Dedication. If the War Cabinet approved this suggestion, the Archbishop of Canterbury would get in touch with the heads of other Churches and concert the necessary plans; and simultaneous announcements would then be made by the Government and the Archbishop. The Home Secretary added that the King had already been pleased to signify his agreement.
316
The War Cabinet-Approved the proposals outlined above for the observance of Armistice Day this year, and authorised the Home Secretary to arrange for the necessary communications and announcements.
Richmond Terrace, S. W. 1, October 5, 1939.
